Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Political Ecology of Large-Scale Logging Initiatives

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Doctoral student Jason Roberts, under the supervision of Dr. Jerry Jacka, will undertake research on the local processes, effects, and responses to large-scale logging in subsistence horticultural communities. The research will take place on New Hanover Island, Papua New Guinea (PNG), an excellent test site for exploring the expansion of international logging in the Asian and Pacific region. The international logging industry has recently developed a much greater presence throughout PNG as previous sources of timber in the Southeast Asian tropics have been progressively logged out. As well, the conditions for international business have become more favorable with the enactment of natural resource driven development policies within PNG. These national policies coincide with local desires for improved socioeconomic benefits, and natural resource extraction remains one of the few means by which many Papua New Guineans can hope to realize these goals. Studies have demonstrated that large-scale logging in the tropical forests of developing countries is detrimental to these ecological systems and the human populations that depend upon them for subsistence. What is not as clear is how local people and local landscapes respond to the enduring effects of logging.

Using ethnographic and ecological research methods, this study compares the results of clearcut and selective logging development schemes on New Hanover Island. Participant observation and interviews at various scales, from the local to the national, will examine changing livelihoods and development policies under different logging and related agricultural development regimes. Ecological sampling techniques and remote sensing data analysis will quantify changes in local forest structure and growth, as well as changes in local subsistence production.

This study combines theoretical interests in development and globalization, political ecology, and land-change science to inform our understanding of the relationships between natural resource based development, forest sustainability, and horticulturalist resilience. It is designed to promote interdisciplinary conversations in both the social and natural sciences by producing theory and data about the interconnections between social and environmental change that could be used to inform future policy.

Overview of the Study

This study examined the local processes, effects, and responses to large-scale logging and commercial agriculture development efforts in subsistence communities on New Hanover island (Lavongai), Papua New Guinea (PNG). New Hanover recently became the site of three large special agriculture and business leases (SABLs) that combined to cover over 75% of the island. SABLs are an outcome of recent resource driven national development policies within PNG. As such, they are designed to promote the development of long-term commercial agriculture industries in rural locations across the country through the conversion of forested lands and the simplification of communal land ownership. At the same time, SABLs have often provided a loophole around more restrictive national forestry policies in PNG, and thereby have become attractive to traditional logging interests in the Asian/Pacific region looking for new sources of timber.  It is within this context that this study combined interests in cultural anthropology, political economy, and environmental science to inform our understanding of the relationships between extractive development, forest sustainability, and local livelihoods.

This project specifically looked at how local livelihoods and environments had been changed as a result of development efforts, what strategies were being used in response to these changes, whether certain segments of the local population were disproportionately effected by these changes, and how broader economic and environmental policies were understood and executed at the local level. Sixteen months of research was undertaken, using a  combination of anthropological and environmental methods. Fourteen months was spent conducting research on New Hanover and two months was spent conducting interviews on economic and environmental policy issues in the province and national capital.

Findings

Overall, the majority of the residents of New Hanover involved with SABL and similar logging and agricultural development projects believed these projects had generally failed to deliver the type of social and economic benefits promised upon inception. Locals were being paid timber royalties well below market value and left with either no commercial agriculture development or poorly planned and implemented agricultural plantings with no clear market or prospects for future viability. What benefit that did reach the local level was primarily directed at select individuals labeled "landowners" by the development companies working in the area. This practice led to social unrest and disunity because land on New Hanover is not individually owned, it is owned collectively by clans. The issues surrounding the distribution of benefits from these development projects, along with the ways in which land was originally leased for the purposes of development, has led to a movement toward customary land registration and an overall narrowing of social relations on the island as a response to threats to land and resource control. 

Water pollution arising from land clearance, road construction, and poor environmental practices related to waste disposal and waterway buffering was a primary environmental effect attributed to the development processes occurring on the island. Water pollution led to an increased incidence of illness. Water pollution also led to a significant reduction in local fish populations in the areas of heaviest development activity. Protein deficiency was a problem in these areas, as fish is the primary meat consumed on New Hanover. Development activities also led to a significant decline in soil fertility and people were changing gardening and other labor practices in response.
